results.title: Revolution of necessity
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
The discovery of how to turn coke into fuel launches the Industrial Revolution. The need for better pumps in the mines eventually leads to the steam engine, which together with the railway transforms society. Bessemer’s converter gives the world cheap steel.

results.title: Revolution's orphans
results.creator_credit: John Smith, Roman Kroitor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In 1956 the Hungarian Revolution claimed 50,000 lives. Clara and her father were two refugees who came to Canada to settle, fleeing the treachery of the secret police. Both were haunted by the events they had experienced. It takes the arrival of Clara’s Uncle Janos from Budapest to explain to her the years of uncertainty and bitterness she had lived through since her childhood escape.

results.title: Revolution
results.creator_credit: Hugh Hudson, Irwin Winkler, Viking, Goldcrest and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: The personal story of Tom Dobb, a reluctant soldier in the American Revolution, his son Ned and the renegade aristocrat Daisy McConnahay is set against the larger backdrop of the American Revolution and what it has come to mean. Stars Al Pacino, Nastassia Kinski and Donald Sutherland with Joan Plowright and Annie Lennox.

results.title: Revolting Rhymes
results.brief_description: In this animated film, Roald Dahl, the master of comic stories for children retells the stories of “Snow White”, “Jack and the beanstalk”, “Little Red Riding Hood”, “The three little pigs”, “Goldilocks and the three bears” and “Cinderella” introducing colourful and amusing twists to these well known stories. The animation is based on the original illustrations by Quentin Blake.

results.title: Revolt of Job = Job lazadasa [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Imre Gyongyossy, Barna Kabay, Antal Gottmann, Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen, Hungarian TV and Mafilm Tarsulas Studio
results.brief_description: An elderly Jewish farming couple living in Nazi-occupied Eastern Hungary, have spent a lifetime attempting to bear healthy offspring, but none of their seven children have survived. It is 1943 and with the Holocaust looming, they are determined not to let their spiritual heritage and worldly possessions disappear with their demise. They adopt a seven-year-old Gentile orphan and though the boy is initially rebellious and distrustful, the love, patience and understanding he receives from his adoptive parents win him over. Just as the three have formed a strong and loving family bond, the Nazi’s round-up of Jews begins and the parents must find a way to protect the boy. Full of humour, compassion, and beauty, this tragic story features a superbly natural performance from Gabor Feher as the boy, which lends it a special poignancy. In Hungarian with English subtitles. Cast also includes Ferenc Zenthe and Hedi Temessy.

results.title: Revolt into style
results.creator_credit: Mark Worth, Simon Burton and Kind Eye Pictures
results.brief_description: Documentary about Melbourne’s Fashion Design Council (FDC) and the hey-day of 1980’s Austalian fashion -a time when models skipped and danced down the catwalk to the sounds of analogue synth pop. Fueled by the energy of the DIY Punk and New wave scene the FDC was formally established in 1984 and made fashion a crucial part of the Art School/Music nexus of underground creativity in Melbourne.

results.title: Reviewing the Australian New Wave panel discussion with David Stratton
results.brief_description: The 1960s brought on a change in government in Australia, resulting in greater funding towards the arts and Australia’s film industry in particular. In turn, this political change gave rise to what was to be called the ‘Australian New Wave’ in cinema. Celebrated film critic, David Stratton, shares his recollections of this pivotal time with fellow key players: Jan Chapman, Matt Carroll, Paul Cox and Phillip Noyce (via SKYPE). This panel discussion was filmed at ACMI as part of the ‘Margaret and David: 25 years talking movies’ exhibition.
